general_electives.name: Introductory Course in French

reviews.comment: Great introduction to French! The instructor made learning fun and engaging.
Enjoyed learning French basics. Good for beginners.

general_electives.description: Learn the basics of French language including grammar, vocabulary, and conversation skills for real-life communication.
objectives: Introduce the basics of French language to students with minimal or no prior knowledge
Help acquire skills in writing and speaking in French, comprehending written and spoken French
Train students to introduce themselves and others, carry out short conversations, ask for simple information
Focus on real life language use, integration of French and francophone culture
topics: Communicative skills: Greetings, personal information, phone conversations, describing people and places
Grammar: Pronouns, nouns, articles, regular and irregular verbs, adjectives, negation, tenses
Vocabulary: Countries, professions, numbers, colors, food, family, places
Phonetics: Pronunciation, accent, intonation, vowel and consonant sounds
outcomes: Communicate in simple everyday situations with basic grammatical structure
Develop oral and reading comprehension skills as well as speaking and writing
Understand simple information in authentic materials like posters and advertisements
Write simple messages, letters, and dialogues
Express feelings, preferences, wishes and display basic francophone awareness
books: Alter ego-1: Méthode de français by Annie Berthet et al., Hachette
Connexions-1: Méthode de français by Régine Mérieux, Didier
Version Originale-1 by Monique Denyer, Maison des Langues
Campus-1 by Jacky Girardet, CLE International

general_electives.name: Introduction to Cognitive Science

reviews.comment: Fascinating subject! Learned about how the mind works.
Mind-blowing course. Changed my perspective on cognition.

general_electives.description: Explore the interdisciplinary study of mind and intelligence from philosophy, psychology, neuroscience, linguistics, and AI perspectives.
objectives: Introduce the study of intelligence, mind and brain from interdisciplinary perspective
Understand contemporary views of how the mind works and nature of reason
Learn modern computational theory of mind
Understand mechanisms through which brain processes language and develops consciousness
topics: Overview: Newell's big question, constituent disciplines, interdisciplinary approach
Philosophy: Mind-body problem, Cartesian dualism, functionalism, Turing Test, consciousness
Psychology: Cognitive revolution, perception, visual cognition, learning and memory, working memory
Linguistics: Grammar components, Chomsky, compositional syntax, semantics, language acquisition
Neuroscience: Brain anatomy, neuroimaging, synaptic transmission, biological learning basis
AI: Turing machines, physical symbol systems, machine learning, cognitive architectures
outcomes: Identify cognitive science as interdisciplinary paradigm across multiple fields
Explain mental processes like memory, attention, and representational techniques
Acquire knowledge of neural networks, linguistic formalism, and the brain
Apply basic AI techniques to solve simple problems
books: Cognitive Science: An Introduction to the Science of the Mind by Bermúdez, Cambridge
Cognitive Science: An Introduction by Friedenberg & Silverman, Sage Publications
Mind: An Introduction to Cognitive Science by Thagard, MIT Press

general_electives.name: Introduction to Corporate Finance

reviews.comment: Good finance basics for non-commerce students.
Learned a lot about corporate finance. Very useful!

general_electives.description: Master fundamental concepts, principles and approaches of corporate finance including financial analysis and decision-making.
objectives: Provide fundamental concepts and principles of corporate finance
Enable students to apply relevant principles in solving corporate finance problems
Understand the role of financial manager and basic financial management decisions
topics: Introduction: Forms of business, financial management decisions, goal of financial management, agency problem
Financial Statements: Balance sheet, income statement, cash flow, ratios, trend and Du Pont analysis
Time Value of Money: Future value, present value, discounting, annuity, DCF valuation
Risk and Return: Systematic and unsystematic risks, CAPM, security market line
Long-term Planning: Sources of financing, cost of capital, leverage, capital structure, M&M propositions
Short-term Management: Working capital, operating cycle, cash management, inventory, credit management
Capital Budgeting: NPV, IRR, payback, profitability index, scenario and sensitivity analysis
Dividend Policy: Residual approach, Walter model, Gordon Model, determinants
Security Valuation: Bond and stock valuation, dividend discount models, yields
outcomes: Understand and apply corporate finance principles
Conduct financial statement analysis using ratios and models
Make informed financial decisions using time value concepts
Evaluate investment opportunities using capital budgeting techniques
books: Principles of Corporate Finance by Brealey, Myers & Allen, McGraw-Hill
Financial Management: Theory and Practice by Ehrhardt & Brigham, Cengage
Fundamentals of Financial Management by Van Horne et al., Pearson
Financial Management by Pandey, Vikas Publishing

general_electives.name: Introduction to Cyber Security

reviews.comment: Excellent intro to cybersecurity. Highly recommend!
Eye-opening course on security. Very relevant today.
Great security fundamentals. Well taught!

general_electives.description: Learn essential cyber security concepts including threats, vulnerabilities, authentication, cryptography, and security management.
objectives: Learn essential building blocks of cyber security
Understand concepts like confidentiality, integrity, availability, authentication, and risk
Explore security across programs, web, operating systems, and networks
topics: Introduction: Threats, vulnerabilities, controls, authentication, access control, cryptography
Programs: Non-malicious oversights, malware, countermeasures
Web Security: Browser attacks, targeting users, email attacks
OS Security: Security in OS design, rootkits
Network Security: Network threats, wireless security, DDoS, firewalls, IDS/IPS
Cloud Computing: Cloud concepts, security tools, identity management, securing IaaS
Privacy: Privacy principles, authentication, data mining, email security, emerging tech
Management: Security planning, business continuity, incident handling, risk analysis
Legal & Ethics: Protecting data, rights, redress, computer crime, ethical issues
Emerging: IoT, economics, computerized elections, cyber warfare
outcomes: Understand technical, social and political aspects of cyber security
Appreciate vulnerabilities and threats from criminals and nation states
Understand secure software development and operating systems
Recognize security management role in cyber defense and legal issues
books: Security in Computing by Pfleeger, Prentice Hall
Applied Cryptography by Schneier, John Wiley & Sons
Information Security: The Complete Reference by Rhodes-Ousley, McGraw-Hill

general_electives.name: Nanoscience and Nanomaterials

reviews.comment: Interesting course on nanotechnology.
Fascinating! Learned about the nano world.

general_electives.description: Introduction to nanoscale science, quantum effects, synthesis methods, characterization techniques, and applications of nanomaterials.
objectives: Introduce basic concepts of nanoscience and advanced nanotechnology applications
Understand quantum effects and properties at nanoscale
Learn synthesis and characterization techniques for nanomaterials
topics: Fundamentals: Features of nanosystems, free electron theory, band structures, density of states
Quantum Size Effect: Quantum confinement, Schrodinger equation, quantum wells, dots, and wires
Nano Materials: Classification, properties, fullerenes, nanotubes, nanowires, thin films, sensors
Synthesis: Sol-gel, cluster beam evaporation, ion beam deposition, chemical bath, ball milling, sputtering
Characterization: XRD, photoluminescence, electron microscopy, Raman, STEM, AFM
Applications: Photonic crystals, smart materials, fuel cells, solar cells, optoelectronic devices
outcomes: Discriminate between bulk and nano materials
Establish size and shape dependence of materials properties
Correlate quantum confinement with physical and chemical properties
Use synthesis methods to create nanoparticles and control their properties
Characterize nanomaterials and apply them in modern technologies
books: Nanotechnology by Booker & Boysen, Wiley India
Nanotechnology by Rogers, Pennathur & Adams, CRS Press
Nano Materials by Bandyopadhyay, New Age International
Nanobiotechnology by Niemeyer & Mirkin, Wiley VCH

general_electives.name: Technologies for Sustainable Development

reviews.comment: Important course for sustainable tech. Highly relevant!
Learned about green technologies. Very inspiring!

general_electives.description: Learn about cleaner production processes, renewable energy technologies, and green design for sustainable industrial development.
objectives: Provide acquaintance with modern cleaner production processes
Understand emerging energy technologies
Facilitate understanding of green and renewable technologies for sustainable development
topics: Sustainability: Industrialization, cleaner production, source reduction, process optimization
Production Techniques: Material substitution, product design, reuse and recycling, waste recovery
Green Design: Green buildings, LEED certification, energy efficient design, passive solar, green materials
Renewable Energy: Solar, wind, tidal, biomass, hydropower, geothermal technologies
Emerging Concepts: Biomolecules and energy, fuel cells, fourth generation energy systems
outcomes: Comprehend basic concepts in source reduction and waste management
Identify and plan cleaner production processes for industrial sectors
Examine present and future advancements in renewable energy technologies
books: Clean Technology and the Environment by Kirkwood & Longley, Chapman & Hall
Pollution Prevention Handbook by World Bank Group
Cleaner Production Audit by Modak, Visvanathan & Parasnis, UNIDP
Energy Technology by Rao & Parulekar, Khanna Publications

general_electives.name: Graph Theory and Applications

reviews.comment: Loved the theoretical depth. Great for CS students!
Solid graph theory course with good applications.

general_electives.description: Study fundamental graph theory concepts including trees, algorithms, planar graphs, and applications to engineering problems.
objectives: Introduce fundamental concepts in graph theory
Provide sense of modern applications of graph theory
Enable use of graph methods in computer science and engineering
topics: Introduction: Graphs, isomorphism, walks, paths, Euler and Hamilton paths, bipartite graphs
Trees: Distance, binary trees, spanning trees, minimum spanning tree
Algorithms: Shortest path, depth-first and breadth-first search, Huffman coding, Warshall's algorithm
Planar Graphs: Kuratowski's theorem, five-color theorem, graph representation
Coloring: Chromatic number, vertex and edge coloring, chromatic polynomial
Applications: Konigsberg bridge, utilities problem, electrical networks, Chinese postman, traveling salesman
outcomes: Understand basic concepts of graphs, directed graphs, and weighted graphs
Understand tree properties and find minimal spanning trees
Understand Eulerian and Hamiltonian graphs
Apply shortest path algorithms to solve problems
Apply graph knowledge to solve real life problems
books: Graph Theory with Application to Engineering by Deo, PHI
Introduction to Graph Theory by West, Pearson Education
Graph Theory with Applications by Bondy & Murty, North Holland
Discrete Mathematics and its Applications by Rosen, Tata-McGraw Hill

general_electives.name: Biology for Engineers

reviews.comment: Good intro to biology for engineering students.
Perfect blend of biology and engineering!

general_electives.description: Learn about living systems, cell biology, genetics, and fundamental biological concepts relevant to engineering applications.
objectives: Learn about living world and basic functioning of biological systems
Understand origin of life, evolution, and central characteristics
Familiarize engineering students with intricate biological phenomena and mechanisms
topics: Characteristics of Life: Living vs non-living, origin, evolution, diversity, classification, phylogenetics
Biological Systems: Cell as basic unit, organelles, biomacromolecules (carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, DNA)
Cell Membrane: Structure, selective permeability, active and passive transport, channels and pumps
Genetics: Heredity, laws of genetics, DNA structure, central dogma, replication, transcription, translation
outcomes: Explain characteristic features of living systems vs non-living
Broaden engineering knowledge by applying concepts of living systems
Demonstrate familiarity with biological macromolecules
Understand biological systems by drawing parallels with thermodynamics
Design engineering products inspired by living creatures
Plan computational applications in bioinformatics
books: Lehninger: Principles of Biochemistry by Nelson & Cox, WH Freeman
A Textbook of Biology by Dhami, Srivastava & Chopra, Pradeep Publications
Textbook of Biotechnology by Das, John Wiley & Sons
Essential Cell Biology by Albert, Taylor & Francis

general_electives.name: Advanced Numerical Methods

reviews.comment: Excellent course on numerical analysis. Very useful!
Learned advanced computational methods. Great course!

general_electives.description: Master advanced numerical techniques for solving non-linear equations, polynomial equations, differential equations, and complex mathematical problems.
objectives: Motivate students to understand advanced numerical techniques
Learn methods to solve mathematical problems governing engineering and physical problems
topics: Non-Linear Equations: Multiple roots, Muller's method, Newton-Raphson for systems and complex roots
Polynomial Equations: Descartes' rule, Birge-Vieta, Giraffe's methods
Linear Systems: Cholesky, partition methods, SOR with optimal relaxation
Eigen-Values: Similarity transformations, Gerschgorin's bounds, Given's and Rutishauser methods
Interpolation: Cubic and B-spline, bivariate interpolation, least squares, Gram-Schmidt, Legendre and Chebyshev
Differentiation & Integration: Using cubic splines, Romberg integration, multiple integrals
Differential Equations: Milne's, Adams-Moulton, shooting and finite difference methods
outcomes: Find multiple roots and apply Newton-Raphson for complex roots and non-linear systems
Obtain numerical solutions of polynomial equations using advanced methods
Apply Cholesky, Partition and SOR to solve linear systems
Approximate functions using spline and least square methods
Solve definite integrals and boundary value problems numerically
books: Applied Numerical Analysis by Gerald & Wheatley, Pearson Education
Elements of Numerical Analysis by Gupta, MacMillan India
Introduction to Numerical Analysis by Atkinson, John Wiley
Elementary Numerical Analysis by Conte & Boor, Tata McGraw Hill
Numerical Methods by Jain, Iyengar & Jain, New Age International

general_electives.name: Campus 2 Corporate

reviews.comment: Must-take before placements! Very practical.
reviews.pros: Interview prep, Resume building, Communication skills

reviews.comment: Helped me crack my dream job interview!
Excellent placement preparation course!

general_electives.description: Bridge the gap between academic learning and corporate requirements with practical skills, industry insights, and professional development.
objectives: Prepare students for corporate environment transition
Develop practical skills required in industry
Provide insights into corporate culture and expectations
topics: Professional Skills: Communication, presentation, and teamwork
Corporate Culture: Work ethics, professionalism, and workplace behavior
Industry Requirements: Technical skills, problem-solving, and adaptability
Career Development: Resume building, interview skills, and networking
outcomes: Understand corporate expectations and work culture
Develop essential professional and soft skills
Prepare effectively for job interviews and career opportunities
Build strong professional network and personal brand

basket_electives.description: Master advanced computing technologies including cloud, GPU, and parallel processing

reviews.comment: Excellent basket for those interested in HPC. All courses are well-coordinated.
Great learning experience. GPU computing was my favorite!

courses.name: Cloud Computing
courses.description: Learn cloud infrastructure, services, virtualization, and implementation with hands-on experience in AWS, Hadoop, and modern cloud technologies.
objectives: Learn the concepts of cloud infrastructure and services in addition with its implementation for assessment of understanding the course by the students
topics: Introduction and Evolution: Computing paradigms, business drivers, cluster and grid computing, XaaS offerings, security issues, impact on education
Cloud Implementations: Amazon Web Services (EC2, S3, SQS), AWS Identity Management, RESTful Web Services
Virtualization: Types (server, storage, network), VMware vCloud IaaS, Software Defined Networks, green data centers, server consolidation
Cloud Storage: Hadoop ecosystem (Pig, Hive, Cassandra, Spark), NoSQL databases, MapReduce framework, data replication
Related Technologies: Fog and Edge Computing, IoT and Big Data analytics, Google AppEngine, Windows Azure, role in smart healthcare
Sustainability: Cloud sustainability importance, global regulations, carbon footprint measurement, green software principles
outcomes: Comprehend the basic concepts and architecture of Cloud computing
Implement Cloud Services through AWS offerings and Restful web services
Apply the knowledge of virtualization through different virtualization technologies
Perform operations on data sets using Map Reduce framework, SQL and NO SQL databases
books: Cloud Computing: Principles and paradigms by Buyya, Broberg & Goscinski, MIT Press (2011)
Distributed and Cloud Computing by Hwang, Fox & Dongarra, Morgan Kaufmann (2012)
Cloud Computing by Miller, Que Publishing (2008)
Cloud Computing: Concepts, Technology & Architecture by Puttini & Mahmood, Service Tech Press (2013)
courses.lab_work: Implement Cloud, Apache and Hadoop framework basics, MapReduce Java API, HDFS, RESTful Web Services, virtualization concepts, data storage, and MapReduce algorithms.
courses.self_learning: Cloud models, computing issues and challenges like Security, Elasticity, Resource management, Scheduling, QoS, Resource Allocation, Cost Management, Cloud bursting.

courses.name: GPU Computing
courses.description: Study GPU architecture and master programming techniques using CUDA, OpenCL, and OpenACC for massively parallel computing applications.
objectives: To study architecture and capabilities of modern GPUs and learn programming techniques for the GPU such as CUDA programming model
topics: Introduction: Heterogeneous parallel computing, modern GPU architecture, power-efficient designs (DVFS, low power states), speeding up real applications, programming languages and models, energy consumption in data centers
GPU History: Evolution of graphics pipelines, fixed-function to programmable graphics, unified processors, GPGPU, scalable GPUs, recent developments and future trends
Data Parallelism & CUDA: Data parallelism concepts, CUDA program structure, vector addition kernel, device memory and data transfer, kernel functions and threading, parallelization techniques

Execution Model: Thread organization, mapping threads to multidimensional data, matrix multiplication kernel, synchronization, transparent scalability, resource assignment, thread scheduling and latency tolerance
CUDA Memories: Memory access efficiency, device memory types, tiled matrix multiplication, memory as parallelism limiting factor
OpenCL: Data parallelism model, device architecture, kernel functions, device management and kernel launch, electrostatic potential map
OpenACC: Comparison with CUDA, execution and memory models, basic programs, parallel and loop constructs, kernels construct, data management, asynchronous operations
outcomes: Comprehend commonly used terms in parallel computing
Understand common GPU architectures and Programming Models
Implement algorithms efficiently for common application kernels
Develop efficient parallel algorithms to solve given problems
books: CUDA by Example by Sanders & Kandrot, Addison-Wesley (2012)
Programming Massively Parallel Processors by Kirk & Hwu, Morgan Kaufmann (2016)
Introduction to Parallel Computing by Grama et al., Addison Wesley (2003)
GPU Computing Gems Emerald Edition by Hwu, Morgan Kaufmann (2011)
courses.lab_work: Practice programs using CUDA, OpenCL and OpenACC for GPU computing.
courses.self_learning: Basics of Parallel and distributed Computing, CUDA programming model.

courses.name: Parallel & Distributed Computing
courses.description: Master parallel architectures, algorithm design, MPI programming, CUDA model, and distributed computing concepts for high-performance applications.
objectives: Learn fundamentals of parallel and distributed computing including parallel architectures and paradigms
Apply parallel algorithms and key technologies
Develop basic parallel applications using programming models and tools
topics: Parallelism Fundamentals: Scope and issues, parallelism goals, parallelism and concurrency, multiple simultaneous computations

Parallel Architecture: Implicit parallelism, array and vector processors, Flynn's Taxonomy (UMA, NUMA), cache coherence, Feng's and Handler's classifications, memory system limitations, interconnection networks, communication costs, routing mechanisms, process-processor mapping, GPU, energy-efficient hardware and cooling

Parallel Decomposition & Performance: Algorithm design principles, decomposition and mapping techniques, load balancing, energy-efficient algorithms, critical paths, overhead sources, performance metrics and measurement, granularity effects

Distributed Computing: Definition, relation to parallel systems, synchronous vs asynchronous execution, design challenges, distributed computation models, communication networks, global state, process communication models
Message Passing & Shared Address: Send/receive operations, MPI interface, topologies and embedding, overlapping communication with computation, groups and communicators
CUDA Programming: Overview, data isolation, memory allocation on device, kernel function launching, data transfer to host, API function calls

Parallel Algorithms: Design, analysis, and programming, graph algorithms, green scheduling, matrix computations, critical paths and Amdahl's law, speedup and scalability, algorithmic patterns (divide-conquer, map-reduce), parallel merge sort, sustainability in distributed systems
outcomes: Apply the fundamentals of parallel and distributed computing including parallel architectures and paradigms
Apply parallel algorithms and key technologies
Develop and execute basic parallel applications using basic programming models and tools
Apply shared address space and message passing in programming platforms
Analyze the performance issues in parallel computing and trade-offs
books: Principles of Parallel Programming by Lin & Snyder, Addison-Wesley (2008)
Introduction to Parallel Computing by Grama et al., Addison Wesley (2003)
Heterogeneous Computing With OpenCL by Gaster et al., Morgan Kaufmann (2011)
Patterns for Parallel Programming by Mattson, Sanders & Massingill, Addison-Wesley (2004)
Parallel Programming in C with MPI and OpenMP by Quinn, McGraw-Hill (2004)
courses.lab_work: Implement parallel programming using CUDA with emphasis on developing applications for processors with many computation cores, mapping computations to parallel hardware, efficient data structures, paradigms for efficient parallel algorithms.
courses.self_learning: Thread basics, synchronization primitives in Pthreads, controlling thread attributes, composite synchronization constructs, asynchronous program design, CUDA API functions, threads/blocks/grids concepts, kernel function development, parallel graph algorithms (shortest path, spanning tree), producer-consumer and pipelined algorithms.

courses.name: Simulation & Modelling
courses.description: Learn to create mathematical models of physical systems and their simulation for analysis, including queuing, inventory, and real-world applications.
objectives: To become familiar with fundamentals of creating mathematical model of physical systems and their simulation for analysis
topics: Introduction to Modeling: Basic concepts, advantages, disadvantages, applications, limitations, model types, continuous vs discrete simulation, analog vs digital, system environment, components, simulation study steps, queuing and inventory system simulation
Random Numbers: Pseudo-random generators, testing pseudo-random generators, generation of non-uniformly distributed random numbers
Parallel Process Modeling: Using Petri nets and finite automata, cellular automata in simulation
Simulation Experiments: Run length of static and dynamic stochastic experiments, minimizing variability without increasing simulation runs
Simulator Design: Application simulators for multi-server queuing, PERT, optimizing inventory policy and cost in business
Input Modeling: Data collection, distribution identification with data, parameter estimation, goodness of fit tests, selection without data, multivariate and time series analysis
Verification & Validation: Model building, verification, calibration and validation
Output Analysis: Simulation types with respect to output, stochastic nature of output data, performance measures and estimation, terminating simulation analysis, steady state simulation analysis

Sustainability: Role in environmental sustainability (climate modeling, resource optimization), sustainable practices in education, healthcare, and urban planning, ethical considerations and long-term impact, energy-efficient simulation techniques, reducing carbon footprint through cloud-based simulation, eco-friendly computational models
outcomes: Describe the role of various elements of discrete event simulation and modeling paradigm
Conceptualize real world situations related to systems development decisions, originating from source requirements and goals
Generate and test random number variates and apply them to develop simulation models
Interpret the model and apply the results to resolve critical issues in a real-world environment
Classify various simulation models and their usage in real-life applications
books: Introduction to Simulation: Programming Techniques and Methods of Analysis by Payne, McGraw Hill (1982)
System Simulation by Gorden, Prentice Hall (1978)
Systems Simulation with Digital Computer by Narsingh, PHI Publication (2004)
Discrete Event System Simulation by Banks et al., Pearson Education (2010)
courses.lab_work: Work on simulation tools, implementation of techniques to generate random numbers, apply simulation models in real life applications.
courses.self_learning: Different Simulation Softwares and their applications for different analysis, Trends in Simulation Software.

courses.name: Green Computing
courses.description: Explore sustainable computing practices, energy-efficient systems, and environmental impact of technology with practical implementations.
objectives: Understand the environmental impact of computing and learn sustainable practices
Study energy-efficient hardware and software solutions
Implement green computing principles in real-world applications
topics: Introduction to Green Computing: Environmental impact of ICT, carbon footprint, e-waste management, sustainable development goals
Energy-Efficient Hardware: Low-power processors, energy-efficient memory systems, green data centers, cooling technologies
Software Optimization: Energy-aware algorithms, code optimization for efficiency, virtualization for resource consolidation
Renewable Energy in Computing: Solar-powered systems, wind energy integration, energy storage solutions
Green Cloud Computing: Energy-efficient cloud architectures, carbon-aware scheduling, sustainable cloud services
E-waste Management: Recycling technologies, circular economy in electronics, responsible disposal practices
Green IoT: Energy harvesting in IoT devices, low-power communication protocols, sustainable sensor networks
Policy and Standards: Green computing certifications, environmental regulations, corporate sustainability practices
outcomes: Analyze the environmental impact of computing systems and identify opportunities for improvement
Design and implement energy-efficient hardware and software solutions
Apply green computing principles to reduce carbon footprint in IT infrastructure
Evaluate and recommend sustainable practices for organizations
books: Green Computing: Tools and Techniques by Murugesan & Gangadharan, CRC Press (2012)
The Green Computing Book by Hernandez & Vaezi, CRC Press (2014)
Sustainable ICT: Principles and Practices by Plepys, Springer (2015)
Energy-Efficient Computing by Kim & Chong, Springer (2019)
courses.lab_work: Measure and optimize energy consumption in computing systems, implement power management strategies, develop energy-aware applications, analyze carbon footprint of IT infrastructure.
courses.self_learning: Current trends in green computing, case studies of sustainable data centers, emerging renewable energy technologies for computing, green AI and machine learning practices.

basket_electives.description: Learn game development, 3D modeling, and immersive technologies

reviews.comment: Amazing basket! Built complete games and VR apps.
Best basket for game dev enthusiasts!

courses.name: Computer Vision
courses.description: Understand basic concepts of Computer Vision and apply various techniques in real-world applications with hands-on implementation.
objectives: To understand the basic concepts of Computer Vision
The student must be able to apply the various concepts of Computer Vision in other application areas
topics: Digital Image Formation and Sustainable Image Preprocessing Techniques: Overview and State-of-the-art, Fundamentals of Image Formation, Transformation: Orthogonal, Euclidean, Affine, Projective, etc; Fourier Transform, Convolution and Filtering, Image Enhancement, Restoration, Histogram Processing

Image Representation & Description: Optimizing algorithms for low-energy consumption in edge devices - Canny, LOG, DOG; Lightweight Line detectors (Hough Transform), Corners - Harris and Hessian Affine, Orientation Histogram, SIFT, SURF, HOG, GLOH, LBP and its variants, Gabor Filters and DWT

Image Segmentation: Region Growing, Edge Based approaches to segmentation, Graph-Cut, Mean-Shift, MRFs, Texture Segmentation; Lightweight and energy-efficient object detection models (e.g., YOLO Nano, MobileNet SSD)

Pattern Analysis: Clustering: K-Means, Fuzzy C-means; Classification: Discriminant Function, Supervised, Un-supervised, Semi-supervised; Reducing data dimensionality to lower computational costs and storage requirements: PCA, LDA, ICA
Motion Analysis: Background Subtraction and Modeling, Optical Flow, KLT, Spatio-Temporal Analysis, Dynamic Stereo; Motion parameter estimation
courses.self_learning: Miscellaneous: Applications: CBIR, CBVR, Activity Recognition, computational photography, Biometrics, stitching and document processing; Modern trends - super-resolution; GPU, Augmented Reality; cognitive models, fusion and SR&CS
courses.lab_work: To implement various techniques and algorithms studied during course.
outcomes: Understand the fundamental problems of computer vision
Implement various techniques and algorithms used in computer vision
Analyse and evaluate critically the building and integration of computer vision algorithms and systems
Demonstrate awareness of the current key research issues in computer vision
books: Szeliski, R., Computer Vision: Algorithms and Applications, Springer-Verlag London Limited (2011), 1st Edition
Forsyth, A., D. and Ponce, J., Computer Vision: A Modern Approach, Pearson Education (2012) 2nd Edition
Hartley, R. and Zisserman, A., Multiple View Geometry in Computer Vision Cambridge University Press (2003) 2nd Edition
Fukunaga, K., Introduction to Statistical Pattern Recognition, Academic Press, Morgan Kaufmann (1990) 2nd Edition
Gonzalez, C., R. and Woods, E., R. Digital Image Processing, Addison-Wesley (2018) 4th Edition

courses.name: 3D Modelling and Animation
courses.description: Develop skills in 3D Modeling & Animation for multimedia industry, covering modeling, texturing, rigging, and character animation.
objectives: To develop the skill & knowledge in 3D Modeling & Animation

Students will understand the know-how and can function either as an entrepreneur or can take up jobs in the multimedia and animation industry, video studios, edit set-up and other special effects sectors
topics: 3D Object Modelling: Basic modelling concepts, vertices, edges, and faces, basic transformations, pivot points, duplication and merging, extrusion, insetting, modifiers, loop cuts and face loops, subdivision methods, coordinate system and exporting, Energy-Efficient rendering model
Low Poly Models: Triangular meshes, objects and mesh data, cursor and origins hidden geometry, Boolean modifiers, geometry from curve, curve resolution, non-planner geometry

3D Character Modelling: Introduction, character modelling, unwrapping UVs & mapping texture, Low-Impact texturing painting, armatures, Eco-Themed Characters rigging, constrained movements, forward and inverse kinematics, time-line, keyframes, character animation, Optimized Rendering Pipelines

Physically Based Modelling and Animation: Introduction, Energy-Efficient Simulations Foundation, Particle based Models, Collision detection and response, Particle System, Particle Simulation, Particle Rendering, Numerical Integration in Particle System, Deformable Meshes, Rigid Bodies and Constrained Dynamics, Fluid Simulation
courses.self_learning: Real Time Animation: Splines and curves, Key-frame techniques, Quaternions for rotations / orientations, Blending and interpolation, Kinematics, Motion capture systems, Motion graphs and character control, Animation data representations, Behavioural Animation, Facial Animation, Perception in animation
courses.lab_work: This course covers beginner to intermediate 3D Modeling and Animation. In this Lab the students will be able to model the 3D character and objects, its UV Mapping, Texture Painting, Rigging, and Animation. Evaluation will be mainly via projects and assignments taking a creative approach to expressive 3D modelling and Animation.
outcomes: Apply modelling concepts in order to implement 3D objects (Blender / Max)
Understand the basic geometry and triangulation techniques behind low poly models
Implement 3D humanoid characters and to apply the concept of rigging for animating the character using key frames
Illustrate the theoretical and practical aspects of 3D Modelling, Key Frame Animation, Simulation & effects
Demonstrate different types of animation and its effects in the real world
Analyse the different processes, post processes involved in computer animation field
books: House, H., D. and Keyser, C., J., Foundations of Physically Based Modeling and Animation, CRC Press (2017) 1st Edition
Chopine, A., 3D Art Essentials: The Fundamentals of 3D Modeling, Texturing, and Animation, Focal Press (2011) 1st Edition
Zeman, B., N., Essential Skills for 3D Modeling, Rendering, and Animation, A K Peters / CRC Press (2017) 1st Edition
Villar, O., Learning Blender: A Hands-On Guide to Creating 3D Animated Characters, Addison Wesley (2017) 2nd Edition
Kerlow, I., The Art of 3D Computer Animation and Effects, Wiley, (2009) 4th Edition
Flavell, L., Beginning Blender: Open Source 3D Modelling, Animation, and Game Design, Apress, (2010) 1st Edition
Boardman, T., 3dsmax 7 Fundamentals, New Riders, (2005) 1st Edition

courses.name: Game Design & Development
courses.description: Become familiar with fundamental and advanced gaming concepts including math, physics, and practical game development using Unity 3D.
objectives: To become familiar with various fundamental and advanced gaming concepts including basic maths and physics used behind the game engine
topics: Introduction: Types of games, History, Impact of Games on Society, Game life cycle, Game loop, Components of game, Model and scene rendering, State Management, Scene management, Texture compression, Level of details, Frustum culling, Occlusion culling, Game as a software, Steps for Game Design, Data Structure for Game, CPU vs.GPU, Game Engine, Components of game engine, Linear Transformation, Composite transformation

Fundamental Gaming concepts: Static and Dynamic Game objects, Vectors, Concept of Time, Lighting, Particle System, Collider, Collision handles, Materials, Texture mapping, Input Process, Object replication, Instantiation, Special Effects, Terrain, Audio design and production, Ray Casting

Maths behind Game Engines: Introduction to Vectors- Addition & Subtraction, Vector length, Scaling, Unit length vectors, Dot & Cross product, Linear Interpolation, Euler Angles, Intersection, Matrices, Coordinate systems, Projections, Triangle Meshes, Optimizations, Quaternion

courses.name: Computer & Network Security
courses.description: Imparts critical theoretical and detailed practical knowledge of computer network security technologies and tools.
objectives: To impart critical theoretical and detailed practical knowledge of a range of computer network security technologies
To provide hands-on experience with network security tools
topics: Introduction: Security Attacks, Security Services, Security Mechanisms and Principles, Security goals, Malicious software, Worms, Viruses, Trojans, Spyware, Botnets, Life cycle of a vulnerability: CAN and CVE, Environmental impact of network security infrastructure, e-waste, and lifecycle analysis

Computer Security: Set-UID programs, privileged programs, environment variables: hidden inputs, capability leaking, invoking other programs, principle of least privileges. Environment variables and attacks, attacks via dynamic linker, external program and library. Shellshock attack, exploiting shellshock vulnerability. Buffer overflow attacks: program memory layout, stack and function invocation. Writing a shell code, injecting code into buffer, address space layout randomization, Stack Guard

Network Security: Packet sniffing and spoofing, Attacks on TCP protocol, SYN flood, TCP reset attack, session hijacking attack, Firewalls: Packet filter, Stateful firewall, Application firewall. IP tables, DNS poisoning, Authoritative replies, ARP poisoning, Heartbleed Bug and Attack, Public key infrastructure and Transport Layer Security, Optimizing network security for energy-efficient data transmission
courses.self_learning: Advanced topics in network security, penetration testing methodologies, security auditing practices
courses.lab_work: Demonstrate use of Environment variables and privileged programs, Implementing secure network protocols with resource optimization, Demonstrate Buffer Overflow and showcase EIP and other register status, insert malicious shell code into a program file and check its malicious or benign status, perform ARP poisoning, implement stateful firewall using IPTables
outcomes: Identify software vulnerabilities and apply various security mechanisms to protect against security attacks
Demonstrate shellshock attack and its countermeasure
Demonstrate buffer-overflow attack, locate and fix security leaks in a computer software
Implement firewall and its variants
Implement PKI and TLS
books: Stallings, W., Network Security Essentials, Prentice Hall (2017) 6th Edition
Cheswick, R., W., Bellovin, M., S., and Rubin, D., A., Firewalls and Internet Security, Addison Wesley Professional (2003) 2nd Edition
Wenliang Du, Computer Security: A hands-on approach, CreateSpace (2017)
Graves, K., Certified Ethical Hacking Study Guide, Sybex (2010) 1st Edition
Stallings, W., Cryptography and Network Security, Prentice Hall (2013), 6th Edition

courses.name: Secure Coding
courses.description: Provides understanding of security attacks and knowledge to recognize and remove common coding errors that lead to vulnerabilities.
objectives: To provide understanding of various security attacks
To provide knowledge to recognize and remove common coding errors that lead to vulnerabilities
To outline techniques for developing secure applications
topics: Introduction: Security, CIA Triad, Viruses, Trojans, and Worms, Security Concepts- exploit, threat, vulnerability, risk, attack, Rootkits, Trapdoors, Botnets, Key loggers, Honeypots. Active and Passive Security Attacks

Need for secure systems: Proactive Security development process, Secure Software Development Cycle (SSDLC), Security issues while writing SRS, Design phase security, Development Phase, Test Phase, Maintenance Phase, Writing Secure Code – Best Practices SD3 (Secure by design, default and deployment), Security principles and Secure Product Development Timeline, Case studies on secure coding practices for environmental monitoring systems

Threat modelling process and its benefits: Identifying the Threats by Using Attack Trees and rating threats using DREAD, Risk Mitigation Techniques and Security Best Practices. Security techniques, authentication, authorization. Defense in Depth and Principle of Least Privilege, Threat modeling in smart healthcare and education systems

Software & Web Security: Return-to-libc attack, format string vulnerability. Race condition vulnerability, Dirty COW, PE Code injection. Cross site request forgery: CSRF attacks on HTTP GET and POST services & countermeasures. XSS attack: self-propagating XSS worm, preventing XSS attacks, SQL injection attack & countermeasures. Client-side attacks
courses.self_learning: Advanced secure coding patterns, security testing methodologies, code review best practices
courses.lab_work: In this Lab, student shall learn to recognize and remove common coding errors that lead to vulnerabilities. This lab also gives an outline of the techniques for developing a secure application code, implementing different types of attacks and protection schemes for both software and web security. Evaluation will be mainly based on projects and assignments
outcomes: Demonstrate skills needed to deal with common programming errors and develop secure applications
Implement PE Code injection and demonstrate control hijacking via EIP manipulation
Demonstrate client-side attacks and identify nature of threats to software and incorporate secure coding practices throughout the planning and development of software product
Demonstrate SQL injection, XSS attack and suggest countermeasures for the same
books: Howard, M. and LeBlanc, D., Writing Secure Code, Howard, Microsoft Press (2002) 2nd Edition
Deckard, J., Buffer Overflow Attacks: Detect, Exploit, Syngress (2005) 1st Edition
Wenliang Du, Computer Security: A hands-on approach, CreateSpace (2017)
Swiderski, F. and Snyder, W., Threat Modeling, Microsoft Professional, (2004) 1st Edition
Salt, C., J., SQL Injection Attacks and Defence, Elsevier (2012), 2nd Edition

objectives: To maintain appropriate level of awareness, knowledge and skill required to understand and recreate criminal terminology
To understand Cyber Forensics investigation process
topics: Introduction to Cybercrime: Defining Cybercrime, Understanding the Importance of Jurisdictional Issues, Quantifying Cybercrime, Differentiating Crimes That Use the Net from Crimes That Depend on the Net, working toward a Standard Definition of Cybercrime, Categorizing Cybercrime, Developing Categories of Cybercrimes, Prioritizing Cybercrime Enforcement, Reasons for Cybercrimes, Role of Cybercrime in Hindering Sustainable Development

Understanding the People on the Scene: Understanding Cybercriminals, Profiling Cybercriminals, Categorizing Cybercriminals, Understanding Cyber victims, Categorizing Victims of Cybercrime, Making the Victim Part of the Crime-Fighting Team, Understanding Cyber investigators, Recognizing the Characteristics of a Good Cyber investigator, Categorizing Cyber investigators by Skill Set, Analyzing Gendered Aspects of Cyber Victimization, Digital Literacy and Awareness Campaigns

Computer Investigation Process: Demystifying Computer/Cybercrime, Investigating Computer Crime, How an Investigation Starts, Investigation Methodology, Securing Evidence, Before the Investigation, Professional Conduct, Investigating Company Policy Violations, Policy and Procedure Development, Policy Violations, Warning Banners, Conducting a Computer Forensic Investigation, The Investigation Process, Assessing Evidence, Acquiring Evidence, Examining Evidence, Documenting and Reporting Evidence, Closing the Case

Acquiring, Duplicating and Recovering Deleted Files: Recovering Deleted Files and Deleted Partitions, recovering "Deleted" and "Erased" Data, Data Recovery in Linux, Recovering Deleted Files, Recovering Deleted Partitions, Data Acquisition and Duplication, Data Acquisition Tools, Recovering Data from Backups, Finding Hidden Data, Locating Forgotten Evidence, Defeating Data Recovery Techniques, Responsible Consumption of Digital Resources during Forensic Investigations

Collecting and Preserving Evidence: Understanding the Role of Evidence in a Criminal Case, Defining Evidence, Admissibility of Evidence, Forensic Examination Standards, Collecting Digital Evidence, Evidence Collection, Preserving Digital Evidence, Preserving Volatile Data, Special Considerations, Recovering Digital Evidence, Deleted Files, Computer Forensic Information, Understanding Legal Issues, Searching and Seizing Digital Evidence

Building the Cybercrime Case: Major Factors Complicating Prosecution, Difficulty of Defining the Crime, Jurisdictional Issues, The Nature of the Evidence, Human Factors, Overcoming Obstacles to Effective Prosecution, The Investigative Process, Investigative Tools, Steps in an Investigation, Defining Areas of Responsibility
courses.self_learning: Deleted Partition Recovery Tools, Deleted File Recovery Tools, Data Acquisition and Duplication Tools, Defeating Data Recovery Techniques, Data Recovery Software and Documentation, Computer Forensic Resources, Computer Forensic Training and Certification, Computer Forensic Equipment and Software, Computer Forensic Services
courses.lab_work: Hands with open source tools for forensic investigation process models (from Item confiscated to submitting evidence for lawful action), such as FTK, Sleuth Toolkit (TSK), Autopsy, etc.
outcomes: Familiarize with cybercrime & forensics ontology
Investigation of crime scene and acquisition of digital evidence
Recovery and analysis of digital data of evidential value
Investigate computer based crime and create document for judicial proceedings
books: Shinder L. D., Cross M., Scene of the Cybercrime, Syngress (2008) 2nd ed.
Marcella J. A. and Guillossou F., Cyber Forensics: From Data to Digital Evidence, Wiley (2012)
Nina Godbole, Sunit Belapure, Cyber Security, Wiley (2011)
Marcella J. A. and Menendez D., Cyber Forensics: A Field Manual for Collection, Examining and preserving Evidence of computer crimes. Auerbach Publication (2010), 2nd ed.
Dejey, Murugan, Cyber Forensics, Oxford (2018)

courses.name: Source Code Management

topics: Traditional Software Development: The Advent of Software Engineering, Waterfall method, Developers vs IT Operations conflict

Rise of Agile methodologies: Agile Vs Waterfall Method, Iterative Agile Software Development, Individual and team interactions over processes and tools, working software over comprehensive documentation, Customer collaboration over contract negotiation, responding to change over following a plan

Definition and Purpose of DevOps: Introduction to DevOps, DevOps and Agile, Minimum Viable Product, Application Deployment, Continuous Integration, Continuous Delivery CAMS (Culture, Automation, Measurement and Sharing): CAMS – Culture, Automation, Measurement, Sharing, Test-Driven Development, Configuration Management, Infrastructure Automation, Root Cause Analysis, Blamelessness, Organizational Learning
Cloud Sustainability: Choosing eco-friendly cloud services (e.g., AWS, Azure, or GCP with carbon-neutral data centers) aligns with DevOps goals and sustainability
Typical Toolkit for DevOps: Introduction to continuous integration and deployment, Version control system
Source Code Management History and Overview: Examples - SVN, Mercury and Git, History - Linux and Git by Linus Torvalds

Version Control System: Version control system vs Distributed version control system: Local repository, Advantages of distributed version control system, The Multiple Repositories Models, completely resetting local environment, Revert - cancelling out changes

Define and understand the basic principles and need of DevOps and Continuous Delivery
Understand the history and overview of Source Code Management, along with real-time examples
Differentiate between centralized and distributed version control systems and basic operations in version control systems and Demonstrate the use of various version control systems

Pro Git – Book by Scott Chacon and Ben Straub (available at https://git-scm.com/book/)

Dependency Management: Introduction to dependency management, Best practices for versioning to reduce duplication and waste, how to use source code repositories, managing transitive dependencies, dependency scope and discussion of various tools like Ant, Maven and Gradle, Tools for measuring energy usage in software delivery pipelines

Document and Reporting: Introduction to build document and reporting, incorporating sustainability principles in project documentation, different types of documentation, understanding site life cycle, advance site configurations and reports, generation of unit test reports, generation of code coverage reports, code coverage tools, code coverage pros and cons

Describe dependency management and the associated concepts like repositories, dependency identification and scope, transitive dependencies, and the examples for build tools
Discuss the process of documentation and reporting, using site life cycle, site configuration and generation of unit testing and code coverage reports
Define release cycle and the phases of release, preparing, cleaning and performing goals

Automation Benefits: advantages of automation, Time and efforts saving scenarios, error preventing scenarios, energy efficiency and resource optimization: scenarios/case study

Prerequisites and benefits in efficient delivery cycles, reducing energy consumption, introduction and business drivers of continuous deployment, benefits of continuous deployment

Stages and Anatomy of CI CD: Core continuous integration process and advanced continuous integration process, release process, continuous delivery engineering practices, continuous testing & promotion of builds, continuous monitoring of delivery pipeline for optimized resources usage, understanding continuous feedback process

topics: HTML & CSS: Introduction to HTML, HTML Page Structure, Create HTML document, various elements in HTML, Attributes in HTML, HTML forms, validations, Creating web pages with HTML5, HTML5 features, form validate/no validate, HTML5 canvas, embedding audio and video, drag and drop, HTML5 Local Storage, web workers and server sent events. CSS - inserting CSS in HTML, CSS3, CSS Selectors, Buttons, float and clear, align, Padding, Links, Lists, Tables

JavaScript: What is JavaScript, Importance, What can JavaScript Do?, JavaScript with HTML Attributes, with CSS, Operators, Syntax, Data Types, Functions, Setting up Environment, Variables, Control flow, if-else, switch, loops, JavaScript HTML DOM Elements, String Methods, Arrays, Sorting, Joins, Reduce map

Frontend Architecture: Introduction to Frontend Development, History, MVC, MVP, MVVM & Web Apps, Resource Optimization, Development of AJAX, Introduction to DOM, Basic DOM Manipulation, Reactive Programming, Refreshing ES6 Specifications and Features ECMA Script, ES6 let and const, arrow functions, New Literal Syntax, Classes, Inheritance using extends, Default Parameter Values, Spread Operator (...), Iterators and Generators, Features of React, Practical Application, Why need React, How React Works, Leveraging Virtual DOM, Setting up React

REST API, JSX: Why JSX, Modular and Scalable Design, Embedding JavaScript Expression in JSX, JSX Attributes, Comments, Styling and Representation as Object, The State of the Component, Changing the State, Props of Component, Using Props, Props Validation in React, Similarities Between State & Props. RESTAPI - Intro to API, History of API Development, Development of AJAX, CRUD; GraphQL; HTTP, HTTP 1.1, HTTP/2, Stream prioritization, Introduction to React Native, Setting up React Native, The Expo Client, Working up on the First Project, Style, Flexbox Layout

Node.js: Introduction to Node.js, History, Why Node.js, Node.js Architecture, Features, Working of Node.js, Installation & Setting Up Node, setting up React, REPL Environment, REPL Commands, Variable, Components of Node.js, Local Modules, Module Exports: Export Object, Export Class, Loading Module from Separate Folder, Operating System, File Systems
courses.self_learning: Advanced React patterns, TypeScript with React, Next.js framework
courses.lab_work: Development of full web framework considering both client and server side programming, creation of dynamic web pages with HTML, CSS, JavaScript, building web apps with functional frontend and database connectivity
outcomes: Acquire knowledge and skills for creation of full web framework considering both client and server side programming
Develop a dynamic and interactive WebPages by the use of HTML, XHTML, CSS, Java script and DHTML
Build web apps with fully functional frontend with database connectivity
Undertake transfer of multimedia content over the Internet between the multi platforms web applications through communication protocols and build web API
books: Web Technology: Theory and Practice - M. Srinivasan, Pearson (2012)
Web Technology: Theory and Practice - A. Kumar, CRC Press (2018)
Web programming with HTML, XHTML and CSS, 2e - Jon Duckett, Wiley India
Web technologies: A Computer Science Perspective - Jeffrey C. Jackson, 1st ed., Pearson (2007)

courses.name: DATA ENGINEERING
courses.description: Learn NoSQL databases, MongoDB, JavaScript, indexing, collections, and database management for availability and performance.
objectives: Basic concepts of database, Mongo DB, SQL, and JavaScript
topics: Getting started with MongoDB: NoSQL Databases, Features of MongoDB, Installation overview, Documents, Collections, Databases, What is the NoSQL approach? Why Use the NoSQL Approach, Benefits of NoSQL, Types of Databases, Key-Value Stores, Wide-column Stores/Columnar Databases, Document/Document-store/Document-oriented Databases, Graph-based Databases, Starting and stopping MongoDB

JavaScript in MongoDB: JavaScript in MongoDB, Execution of a JavaScript file in MongoDB, Making the output of find readable in shell, Complementary Terms, Installation, Basic commands on mongo shell, HelloWorld, Create, Update Delete, Read, Update of embedded documents, more update operators, Updating multiple documents

Collections: List all collections in the database, List all databases, Find(), FindOne(), limit, skip, sort and count the results of the find() method, Query Document – Using AND, OR and IN Conditions, find() method with Projection, $set operator to update specified field(s) in document(s), Insert a document, Create a Collection, Drop Collection, Aggregation

Indexes: Indexes, Index Creation Basics, Dropping/Deleting an Index, Sparse indexes and Partial indexes, Get Indices of a Collection, Compound, Unique Index, Single field, Delete, List, Mongo as Shards

Sharding Environment Setup: Managing Database for Availability and Performance, Database Scaling, Database Distribution Models, Database Replication, Types of Database Replication, Master-Slave Replication, Peer-to-Peer Replication, Advantages and Disadvantages of Peer-to-Peer Replication, Introduction to Sharding, Why Sharding, The Lookup Strategy, Basic configuration with three nodes, Mongo as a Replica Set, Mongoose
courses.self_learning: Advanced MongoDB operations, database optimization, NoSQL design patterns
courses.lab_work: Hands-on practice with MongoDB operations, indexing, collections management, sharding, and replication
outcomes: Learn NoSQL, Mongo DB, and JavaScript
Apply basic concepts of indexing and collections using MongoDB
Formulate the basic usage of database such as graph-based database, creating and dropping of collections, and indexing and solving real-world problems
Handle and update multiple documents using Mongo DB
Manage database for availability and performance, and scaling of database
books: The Data Engineering Cook Book - Andreas Kretz, 6th ed. (2019)
Database Internals: A deep dive into how distributed data systems work - Alex Petrov, O'REILLY Publication (2021)
MongoDB: The definite guide: Powerful and Scalable Data Storage - S. Bradshaw, Eoin Brazil, and Kristina Chodorow, O'REILLY Publication (2021)
NoSQL for Mere Mortals - Dan Sullivan, O'REILLY Publication (2021)

courses.name: TEST AUTOMATION
courses.description: Understanding of software testing and how to use various tools like Selenium and TestNG for automation of software testing.
objectives: The course provides understanding of software testing and how to use various tools (like Selenium and TestNG etc.) used for automation of software testing
topics: Introduction to Software Testing: Seven principles of Software Testing, SDLC vs STLC, Testing Life Cycle, Usability Testing, why do we need Usability Testing, how to do Usability testing, Advantages & Disadvantages, Functional Testing, End to End Testing, Methods, Advantages & Disadvantages, Compatibility Testing, Types GUI testing, Techniques API testing, Advantages

Test Automation - Selenium: Selenium components, Selenium Architecture, TestNG: Installing TestNG in Eclipse, TestNG annotations – Understanding usage, setting priority of execution for test cases, Hard Assertion, Soft Assertion, TestNG Reports, ANT- Downloading & Configuring, XSLT report generation using TestNG and Ant

Introduction to Selenium 3.x: Describe Selenium 3.x advantages and implementation, Define drivers for Firefox, IE, chrome, iPhone, Android etc. Analyze first Selenium Code, differentiate between Close and Quit, Describe Firepath and firebug Add-ons installation in Mozilla, inspect elements in Mozilla, Chrome and IE, Identifying Web Elements using id, name, class, Generate own CSS Selectors. Differentiate between performance of CSS Selectors as compared to Xpaths, define class attribute, Handle Dynamic objects/ids on the page, Analyze whether object is present on page or not

Manual Testing: Manual Testing, Manual Testing – How to Approach? Manual Testing – Myth and fallacy, Defect Life Cycle, Qualities of a good Manual Tester, Manual Testing Vs Automation Testing, Types, System Testing, Acceptance Testing, Unit Testing, Techniques, Integration Testing, Smoke-Sanity Testing

Introduction to Test Design and Sustainable Software Testing Practices: Test Scenario, Test Case Design, Test Basis Traceability Matrix, Energy-efficient coding and testing strategies, Integrating sustainable practices in STLC, Balancing scalability and energy consumption during automated testing, Case studies of sustainable software projects
courses.self_learning: Advanced Selenium frameworks, Cypress, Playwright, API testing tools
courses.lab_work: Hands-on implementation of automated tests using Selenium, TestNG, designing test cases, creating test frameworks
outcomes: Understand the concepts related to software testing and test automation
Take into account the different considerations when planning automated tests vs. manual tests
Architect the test project and fit it to the architecture of the tested application
Design and implement highly reliable automated tests
Understand how different types of automated tests will fit into your testing strategy, including unit testing, load and performance testing, visual testing, and more
books: Complete Guide to Test Automation: Techniques, Practices, and Patterns for Building and Maintaining Effective Software Projects - Axelrod Arnon, Apress (2018)
Learn Selenium: Build data-driven test frameworks for mobile and web applications with Selenium Web Driver 3 - Gundecha U. and Cocchiaro C., Packt (2019)
Selenium Fundamentals - Diego Molina, Packt (2018)
Foundations of Software Testing - Aditya P. Mathur, Pearson Education (2008)

courses.name: CLOUD & DEVOPS
courses.description: Teach techniques to automate the process of integration and deployment of software products using DevOps, containerization, and cloud technologies.
objectives: The objective of the course is to teach techniques to automate the process of integration and deployment software product
topics: Introduction to DevOps: Definition of DevOps, Challenges of traditional IT systems & processes, History and emergence of DevOps, DevOps definition and principles governing DevOps, DevOps and Agile, The need for building a business use case for DevOps, Purpose of DevOps, Application Deployment, Automated Application Deployment, Application Release Automation (ARA), Components of Application Release Automation (ARA), Continuous Integration, Best Practices of CI, Benefits of CI, Continuous Delivery

Typical Toolkit for DevOps: DevOps, An Overview, Achieving DevOps, Continuous Practices, Continuous Integration (CI), How does CI Work? Continuous Integration Practices, Benefits of Continuous Integration A Quick Recap of Continuous Delivery, Continuous Delivery Process, Benefits of Continuous Delivery, Continuous Deployment

Source Code Management: History of Version Control Systems (VCS), Basic operations in a VCS, Examples of version control systems, Subversion (SVN), Features and Limitations, Mercurial, Git, Overview, History - Linux and Git by Linus Torvalds, Advantages of Git, Explain how local version control works, Centralized Version Control Systems (CVCS), Distributed Version Control Systems (DVCS), advantages of DVCS, Private Workspace, Easier merging, Easy to scale horizontally, List the disadvantages of DVCS, Explain how CVCS and DVCS compare with each other, Describe the working of the multiple repositories model

Application Containerization Understanding Containers: Transporting Goods Analogy, Problems in Shipping Industry before Containers, Shipping Industry Challenges, Container: Virtualization Introduction, Hypervisor, Scope of Virtualizations, Containers vs Virtual Machines, Understanding Containers, Containerizations Platform, Runtime and Images, Container Platform, Container Runtime, The Chroot System, FreeBSD Jails, LinuX Containers (LXC), Docker

Introduction to Containerization: Docker architecture, Docker Daemon (Container Platform), Docker Rest API, CLI Different environments: (Dev, QA and Prod), Overcoming issues with different environments, virtual machine for dev/deployments, containers for dev/deployments, advantages and drawbacks of containerization
Orchestration Tools: Orchestration: its definition and need, Docker swarm and Kubernetes, AWS (ECS and EKS), Kubernetes on cloud, monitoring containers and its process

Introduction to Provisioning: Basic and software definition, provisioning concepts, reason for exclusive provisioning, configuration management definition and tools, difference between provisioning and configuration management, provisioning tools, test machines for provisioning, deployment and its relationship with provisioning
On Premise Provisioning: Understanding and Defining On Premise, On Premise provisioning infrastructure, Templating, server templating and its challenges

Provisioning on Cloud: defining cloud provisioning, types of cloud provisioning, life-cycle of provisioning on cloud, On Premise cloud mitigation strategies, network security enablement from On Premises to cloud, micro-services management in cloud, Environmental impact of cloud technologies, Benefits of Sustainable System Provisioning

Provisioning and Configuration Management: State of tools in provisioning and configuration, definition and need for configuration management, its benefits and drawbacks in DevOps, need for monitoring in DevOps, reasons for using provisioning and configuration tools, automation, preventing errors and tracking changes, examples of tools and their capabilities
courses.self_learning: Advanced Docker and Kubernetes, Terraform, Ansible, infrastructure as code
courses.lab_work: System Provisioning: Automation of infrastructure, AWS configuration for Terraform, create IAM User, security group, spinning up with EC2 instance, variables, resources, modules, state management, VPC, IAM policy, S3 bucket and its variables. Containers Lab: Playing with Vagrant and understanding its file, Docker machine, Dockerfile, Docker extras, DTR, Docker compose and swarm, Kubernetes -Minikube, deploying Pods and services on Minikube
outcomes: Understand the concept of Virtualization and Containerization
Familiarize with Orchestration and System provisioning
Analyze and demonstrate the infrastructure automation and state management in the cloud environment
Understand and demonstrate the need for configuration management
books: Cloud Native DevOps with Kubernetes: building, deploying, and scaling modern applications in the cloud - Arundel, J., & Domingus, J., O'Reilly Media (2019)
The DevOps Handbook: How to Create World-Class Agility, Reliability, and Security in Technology Organizations - Kim, G., Humble, J., Debois, P., & Willis, J., IT revolution Press 1st ed (2016)
DevOps: A software architect's perspective - Bass, L., Weber, I., & Zhu, L., Addison-Wesley Professional (2015)
Engineering Software as a Service: An Agile Approach Using Cloud Computing - Fox, A., Patterson, D. and Joseph, S., 1st Edition (2013)
Continuous Integration, Delivery, and Deployment: Reliable and Faster Software Releases with Automating Builds, Tests, and Deployment - Rossel, S., Packt Publishing, 1st ed (2017)

basket_electives.description: Advanced mathematical methods and computational techniques

reviews.comment: Strong mathematical foundation with practical computing applications.
Perfect for those who love math and computing!

courses.name: Mathematical Modeling and Simulation
courses.description: Provides students basic knowledge of mathematical modeling and introduces computer simulations and techniques.
objectives: To provide students a basic knowledge of mathematical modeling
To enable students to construct different mathematical models using various mathematical techniques
To introduce computer simulations and techniques
To provide the foundations for the student to understand computer simulation needs
topics: Mathematical Modeling: Modeling and its principles, some methods of mathematical modeling: problem definition, dimensional homogeneity and consistency, abstraction and scaling, conservation and balance principles, system characterization, constructing linear models, discrete versus continuous modelling, determinstic versus stochastic
Approximating and Validating Models: Review of Taylor's formula and various trigonometric expansions, validating the model, error analysis, fitting curves to the data
Basic Simulation Approaches: Methods for simulation and data analysis using MATLAB, statistics for simulations and analysis, random variates generation, sensitivity analysis

Model and its Different Types: Linear and nonlinear population models, traffic flow models, transport phenomena, statistical models, Poisson process, stochastic models, stock market, option pricing, Black-Scholes model, modeling engineering systems
courses.self_learning: Advanced modeling techniques, real-world case studies, complex system simulations
courses.lab_work: Implementation of numerical techniques using MATLAB based on course contents. Projects: The projects will be assigned according the syllabus covered
outcomes: Formulate various mathematical models based on modeling tools and techniques
Derive and use various simulation techniques
Simulate examples based to realistic models using appropriate modeling tools
Implement statistical simulation for various models
books: Clive L. Dym, Principles of Mathematical Modelling, Elsevier Press, Second Edition, 2004
Edward A. Bender, An Introduction to Mathematical Modelling, Dover, 2000
D Kincaid and W. Cheney, Numerical Analysis: Mathematics of Scientific Computing, Third Edition, American Mathematical Society, 2009
J. Nathan Kutz, Data-Driven Modeling& Scientific Computation: Methods for Complex Systems & Big Data, Oxford University Press, 2013

courses.name: Matrix Computation
courses.description: Provides platform for students to use linear algebra in real life with focus on computational methods to compute eigenvalues and singular values.
objectives: To provide a platform for the students to use linear algebra in real life
To focus on computational methods for eigenvalues and singular values computation
To provide Matlab implementation of methods for better understanding
topics: Matrix Analysis: Review of matrices and vector spaces: rank of a matrix, linear dependence and independence, bases and dimensions, linear transformations, range and null space of a matrix, rank-nullity theorem. Inner product space: Gram Schmidt orthogonalization, dual space and invariant space
Matrix transformations: similarity transformation, diagonalization of matrices, Householder transformation, QR factorization
Conditioning of matrices: vector and matrix norms, convergent matrices, condition number of a matrix

Techniques for finding eigen values: Eigen value problems, spectral stability of matrices, reduction to Hessenberg or tridiagonal form, iterative techniques using Krylov subspace concepts for eigen value problems
Spectral theory of matrices: spectral decompositions, Gersgorin bounds on eigenvalues, spectrum of perturbed matrices, Schur decomposition theorem
Singular value decomposition: SVD and their applications
Real life applications of eigen values and singular values: Discussion of real life problems based on eigen values and SVDs and their application in image processing and big data analysis
courses.self_learning: Advanced matrix algorithms, numerical stability analysis, applications in machine learning
courses.lab_work: Matlab experiments will be designed to implement algorithms from the syllabus
outcomes: Explain and apply fundamental linear algebra concepts
Evaluate norms of vectors and matrices
Solve eigen value problems using theoretical and computational methods
Apply singular value decomposition
Implement linear algebra algorithms using Matlab
books: Kenneth Hoffman and Ray Kunze, Linear Algebra, Pearson India, second edition, 2015
Derek J. S. Robinson, A course in linear algebra with application, World Scientific Press, second edition, 2006
Gene H. Golub and Charles F. Van Loan, Matrix Computations, Johns Hopkins University Press, fourth edition, 2012
Roger A. Horn and Charles R. Johnson, Matrix Analysis, second Edition, Cambridge University Press, 2012
L. N. Trefethen and David Bau, Computational Linear Algebra, SIAM, 1997
Gilbert Strang, Linear algebra and its Applications, fourth edition, CENGAGE, 2014

courses.name: Financial Mathematics
courses.description: Introductory course in finance to equip with framework and basic techniques necessary for financial engineering with focus on valuation of financial assets and derivative products.
objectives: To equip with a framework and basic techniques necessary for financial engineering
To focus on valuation of financial assets and more specifically derivative products
To introduce the concept of risk and relation between risk and return
To integrate knowledge of risk and valuation in optimal decision-making
topics: Basics of Financial Mathematics: Financial markets, terminologies, basic definitions and assumptions, Interest rate, present value, future value, NPV, annuity and perpetuity, Market structure, no arbitrage principle, derivative products, forwards, futures – their valuation, dividend and non divided cases, options, swap, valuation concept, purpose and working of these products

Theory of Option Pricing: Options-calls and puts, pay-off, profit diagrams, hedging and speculation properties of options, valuation of options using pricing and replication strategies, mathematical properties of their value functions, put-call parity, Risk neutral probability measure (RNPM) (discrete case), existence of RNPM, Binomial lattice model, Binomial formula for pricing European style and American style options, dividend and non-divided cases, CRR model, Black-Scholes formula derivation, Examples. Greeks and their role in hedging, delta-neutral portfolio, delta-gamma neutral portfolio
Portfolio Optimization: Introduction, risk, return, two-assets portfolio, Markowitz curve, efficient frontier, Multi-assets all risky portfolio, mean-variance Markowitz model, two fund theorem
courses.self_learning: Advanced option pricing models, portfolio theory extensions, risk management techniques
courses.lab_work: Extraction of data from various online resources like NSE, moneyconrol.com etc. Implementation and validation of various models studied in the course for option and portfolio valuation using Matlab/R/Excel
outcomes: Understand basic quantities that are reported in everyday life such as interest rates, periodic payments of money, dividends, shares, bonds, forwards, futures etc.
Evaluate call and put option prices using binomial and CRR models
Construct a portfolio which is optimal in a given market scenario
books: D.G. Luenberger, Investment Science, Oxford University Press, 1999 (new edn. 2013)
S. Chandra, S. Dharmaraja, A. Mehra, R. Khemchandani, Financial Mathematics: An Introduction, Narosa, 2012
M. Capinsky and T. Zastawniak, Mathematics for Finance: An Introduction to Financial Engineering, Springer, 2004 (new edn, 2011)
J C Hull, Options, Futures and other Derivatives, Prentice Hall, 8th edn, 2011
J H Cochrane, Asset Pricing, Princeton University, 2000 (new edn 2005)

courses.name: Computational Number Theory
courses.description: Provides introduction to elementary number theory with focus on computational aspects and applications in cryptography for secure encryption methods.
objectives: To provide an introduction to elementary number theory, including theory of congruences, prime modulo, quadratic residues
To focus on computational aspects and finding applications in cryptography
To deal with secure encryption methods for communication
topics: Divisibility and Primes: Twin primes, Goldbach conjecture, Fermat and Mersenne primes, Primality testing and factorization

Congruences: Linear congruences, Chinese Remainder Theorem, congruences with a prime-power modulus, Fermat's little theorem, Wilson's Theorem, Euler function, Quadratic Residues, Legendre Symbol, Euler's criterion
Cryptography Basics: Symmetric and asymmetric key cryptography, Pseudo-primes, Pseudo-primality Testing, Randomized Primality test & Deterministic Polynomial Time Algorithm, Pollard-Rho Method
Public key Cryptosystems: RSA, Diffie Hellmann key exchange, different attacks and Remedies, Digital Signature, Elliptic curve cryptography and its application in cryptography
courses.self_learning: Advanced cryptographic protocols, post-quantum cryptography, blockchain applications
courses.lab_work: Implementation of various traditional ciphers, symmetric ciphers and asymmetric ciphers using C programming language
outcomes: Find the greatest common factor using the Euclidean Algorithm and investigate different factorization methods and primes
Solve linear and simultaneous congruences
Apply Wilson's and Fermat's Little Theorem as the basis for primality tests and factoring algorithms
Apply and analyse elementary number theory concepts to symmetric and asymmetric key cryptography for encrypting and decrypting a message
books: Neal Koblitz, A course in Number Theory and Cryptography, Springer, 2006
Niven, H.S. Zukermann, H.L. Montgomery, An introduction to theory of numbers, Willey, 2015
D. Burton, Elementary Number Theory, McGraw-Hill, 2012
Behrouz A. Forouzan, D. Mukhopadhyay, Cryptography and Network Security, McGraw Hill, 2015
J. Pipher, J. Hoffstein and J.H. Silverman, An introduction to Mathematical Cryptography, Springer-verlag 2014
